verses.text: And now, my son, I perceive there is somewhat more which doth worry your mind, which ye cannot understand--which is concerning the justice of God in the punishment of the sinner; for ye do try to suppose that it is injustice that the sinner should be consigned to a state of misery.

similars.text: For consider him that endured such contradiction of sinners against himself, lest ye be wearied and faint in your minds.
Why criest thou for thine affliction? thy sorrow is incurable for the multitude of thine iniquity: because thy sins were increased, I have done these things unto thee.
That thou mayest bear thine own shame, and mayest be confounded in all that thou hast done, in that thou art a comfort unto them.
Sigh therefore, thou son of man, with the breaking of thy loins; and with bitterness sigh before their eyes.
Knowing that he that is such is subverted, and sinneth, being condemned of himself.
And also he hath need to repent, for I, the Lord, am not well pleased with him, for he seeketh to excel, and he is not sufficiently meek before me.

Thou also, which hast judged thy sisters, bear thine own shame for thy sins that thou hast committed more abominable than they: they are more righteous than thou: yea, be thou confounded also, and bear thy shame, in that thou hast justified thy sisters.

And as for the perils which I am called to pass through, they seem but a small thing to me, as the envy and wrath of man have been my common lot all the days of my life; and for what cause it seems mysterious, unless I was ordained from before the foundation of the world for some good end, or bad, as you may choose to call it. Judge ye for yourselves. God knoweth all these things, whether it be good or bad. But nevertheless, deep water is what I am wont to swim in. It all has become a second nature to me; and I feel, like Paul, to glory in tribulation; for to this day has the God of my fathers delivered me out of them all, and will deliver me from henceforth; for behold, and lo, I shall triumph over all my enemies, for the Lord God hath spoken it.

Let thine ear now be attentive, and thine eyes open, that thou mayest hear the prayer of thy servant, which I pray before thee now, day and night, for the children of Israel thy servants, and confess the sins of the children of Israel, which we have sinned against thee: both I and my father's house have sinned.

Nevertheless, there are those among you who have sinned exceedingly; yea, even all of you have sinned; but verily I say unto you, beware from henceforth, and refrain from sin, lest sore judgments fall upon your heads.

verses.text: Now behold, my son, I will explain this thing unto thee. For behold, after the Lord God sent our first parents forth from the garden of Eden, to till the ground, from whence they were taken--yea, he drew out the man, and he placed at the east end of the garden of Eden, cherubim, and a flaming sword which turned every way, to keep the tree of life--

And the Lord God planted a garden eastward in Eden; and there he put the man whom he had formed.

For it was spiritual in the day that I created it; for it remaineth in the sphere in which I, God, created it, yea, even all things which I prepared for the use of man; and man saw that it was good for food. And I, the Lord God, planted the tree of life also in the midst of the garden, and also the tree of knowledge of good and evil.
And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden to dress it and to keep it.

verses.text: And thus we see, that there was a time granted unto man to repent, yea, a probationary time, a time to repent and serve God.

verses.text: But behold, it was appointed unto man to die--therefore, as they were cut off from the tree of life they should be cut off from the face of the earth--and man became lost forever, yea, they became fallen man.

verses.text: And now, ye see by this that our first parents were cut off both temporally and spiritually from the presence of the Lord; and thus we see they became subjects to follow after their own will.

similars.text: And this they did, not as we hoped, but first gave their own selves to the Lord, and unto us by the will of God.

verses.text: Now behold, it was not expedient that man should be reclaimed from this temporal death, for that would destroy the great plan of happiness.

similars.text: That he no longer should live the rest of his time in the flesh to the lusts of men, but to the will of God.

None devoted, which shall be devoted of men, shall be redeemed; but shall surely be put to death.
That which he laboured for shall he restore, and shall not swallow it down: according to his substance shall the restitution be, and he shall not rejoice therein.
It is not good to accept the person of the wicked, to overthrow the righteous in judgment.

For godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of: but the sorrow of the world worketh death.
He shall not be rich, neither shall his substance continue, neither shall he prolong the perfection thereof upon the earth.

verses.text: Therefore, as the soul could never die, and the fall had brought upon all mankind a spiritual death as well as a temporal, that is, they were cut off from the presence of the Lord, it was expedient that mankind should be reclaimed from this spiritual death.

similars.text: For whatsoever soul it be that shall not be afflicted in that same day, he shall be cut off from among his people.

verses.text: Therefore, as they had become carnal, sensual, and devilish, by nature, this probationary state became a state for them to prepare; it became a preparatory state.

similars.text: But by the transgression of these holy laws man became sensual and devilish, and became fallen man.

And, behold, there is a place prepared for them from the beginning, which place is hell.

verses.text: Therefore, according to justice, the plan of redemption could not be brought about, only on conditions of repentance of men in this probationary state, yea, this preparatory state; for except it were for these conditions, mercy could not take effect except it should destroy the work of justice.
